definitions.definition: to be unable to find something/somebody

examples.text: I've lost my keys.
The tickets seem to have **got lost**.
She lost her husband in the crowd.
We've lost Alfie—is he with you?
Here, tie it round your neck so you don't lose it.
If your card is lost or stolen, inform your bank immediately.

definitions.definition: to have something/somebody taken away from you, especially as a result of an accident, dying, etc.

examples.text: She lost a leg in a car crash.
Some families **lost everything** *(= all they owned)* in the flood.
She **lost her baby** *(= had a )* three months into the pregnancy.
They lost both their sons *(= they were killed)* in the war.
The ship was **lost at sea** *(= it sank)*.
Many people **lost their lives** *(= were killed)*.

definitions.definition: to have to give up something; to fail to keep something/somebody

examples.text: He's **lost his job**.
You will lose your deposit if you cancel the order.
Sit down or you'll lose your seat.
The government has **lost control** of the city.
We cannot afford to lose any more senior members of staff.
The average business loses 20 per cent of its customers every year.
You **risk losing** your house if you do not keep up the payments.
The company has lost a lot of business to its competitors.

definitions.definition: to no longer have something, or have less of something than you had before, especially as a result of getting older

examples.text: to lose your hair/teeth
to lose your sight/eyesight/hearing/memory
There's new hope for people trying to **lose weight**.
I've lost ten pounds since I started this diet.

definitions.definition: to have less and less of a quality or ability, especially until you no longer have any of it

examples.text: She seemed to have **lost interest** in food.
to lose faith/confidence
He lost his nerve at the last minute.
At that moment he lost his balance and fell.
The train was losing speed.
She never lost the ability to make people laugh.

definitions.definition: to be defeated; to fail to win a competition, a court case, an argument, etc.; to cause somebody to be defeated
definitions.sensetop: lose somethinglose to somebodylose by somethinglose something by somethinglose on something (to somebody)lose somebody something

examples.text: So far they haven't **lost a game**.
to lose a race/an election/a battle/a war
We lost to a stronger team.
He lost by less than 100 votes.
We lost the game by three points.
They **lost on penalties** to *(= because they scored fewer  than) Spain.
Many believe the incident lost them the election.
The visiting side lost to the home team.
There was really no shame in losing to Norton at that stage of his career.
This is a game that Lazio cannot afford to lose.
We lost against Albyn College.
We lost by five goals to two.
They deserved to lose.
Win or lose, the important thing is to remain calm.
The South lost the war.
He yesterday lost his appeal against a six-month ban.
She resigned as party leader after they lost the election.

definitions.definition: to fail to keep something you want or need, especially money; to cause somebody to fail to keep something
definitions.sensetop: lose somethinglose something by doing somethinglose on somethinglose somebody something

examples.text: The business is **losing money**.
Poetry always loses something in translation.
**You have nothing to lose** by telling the truth.
What do we lose by working with them?
We lost on that deal.
The company stands to lose financially if this deal falls through.
His carelessness lost him the job.

definitions.definition: to fail to get, hear or understand something

examples.text: His words were lost *(= could not be heard)* in the applause.

definitions.definition: to be no longer understood by somebody

examples.text: I'm afraid **you've lost me** there.
We managed to lose our pursuers in the darkness.

definitions.definition: to waste time or an opportunity

examples.text: We lost twenty minutes changing a tyre.
Hurry—**there's no time to lose**!
He **lost no time in** setting out for London.

definitions.definition: if a watch or clock loses or loses time, it goes too slowly or becomes a particular amount of time behind the correct time

examples.text: This clock loses two minutes a day.

definitions.definition: to become unable to control your emotions or behaviour

examples.text: Then she just lost it and started screaming.

wordOrigin: Old English losian ‘perish, destroy’, also ‘become unable to find’, from los ‘loss’.
